choking.infant: Give 5 back blows followed by 5 chest thrusts. Do not perform abdominal thrusts on infants.
choking.child: Give abdominal thrusts if the child cannot speak, cry, or breathe.
choking.adult: Perform abdominal thrusts until the object is dislodged or help arrives.

burn.default: Cool the burn under running water for 10 minutes. Cover with sterile dressing.

cut.default: Clean the wound, apply pressure to stop bleeding, then cover with a bandage.

fracture.default: Immobilize the injured area. Do not attempt to straighten the limb. Apply a splint if trained, and seek medical help immediately.

bleeding.default: Apply direct pressure to the wound with a clean cloth. Raise the injured area if possible. Seek medical help if bleeding is severe.

fever.infant: Seek medical advice immediately for infants under 3 months with fever. Keep the infant hydrated.
fever.child: Give age-appropriate fever-reducing medication and monitor. Keep child cool and hydrated.
fever.adult: Rest, stay hydrated, and use fever-reducing medication like acetaminophen if needed.

sprain.default: Follow the R.I.C.E. method: Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation. Avoid putting weight on the area.

headache.default: Rest in a quiet, dark room. Drink water. Take a pain reliever if necessary. Seek help if severe or sudden.

poisoning.default: Call emergency services or a poison control center immediately. Do not induce vomiting unless instructed by a professional.

unconsciousness.default: Check responsiveness. Call emergency services. If not breathing, begin CPR. Place in recovery position if breathing resumes.

nosebleed.default: Sit the person up and lean them forward. Pinch the soft part of the nose for 10 minutes. Do not tilt the head back.

seizure.default: Do not restrain the person. Clear the area around them. Place something soft under their head. Call for help if it lasts more than 5 minutes.

allergic reaction.default: If severe, use an epinephrine auto-injector and call emergency services. For mild reactions, use antihistamines.

asthma attack.default: Help the person sit upright and use their inhaler. If no improvement, call emergency services.
